snippet: Dasani, part of New York’s vast and invisible tribe of homeless children, lives in one of the most unequal pockets of the most unequal metropolis in America.
abstract: Dasani, age 11, one of New York City’s 22,000 homeless children, lives in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, a neighborhood profoundly divided by two economies that are an experiment born of meteoric gentrification; Fort Greene has been remade in last decade, with portion of white residents jumping by 80 percent as real estate prices more than doubled despite recession; graphs highlight income inequalities (Series: Invisible Child).

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Rebecca R. Ruiz, and research by Ms. Ruiz, Joseph Burgess, Alain Delaquérière and Ramsey Merritt.

lead_paragraph: Dasani, part of New York’s vast and invisible tribe of homeless children, lives in one of the most unequal pockets of the most unequal metropolis in America.

headline.main: A Profound Divide in a Neighborhood Transformed
headline.print_headline: A Profound Divide in a Neighborhood Transformed
